body:
Same issue on Debian testing. 

![Screenshot_2021-01-07_08-11-21](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3475462/103896523-1a4b0880-50c0-11eb-8e38-305429528d33.png)

`export QT_SCALE_FACTOR=1.1` fixes it on this end.

I could have sworn we had a ticket for this already. Hmm.

This can be considered a known issue, basically we added improved scaling support (as did our UI library, Qt) which supports fractional scaling.

Unfortunately, it seems to misbehave on Linux. The plan is to verify whether the fractional scaling support causes any issues on macOS, and then submit a PR that disables it on (at least) Linux.

Those of you who run into this - what version of Qt are you running?

```
~ % qmake-qt5 --version
QMake version 3.1
Using Qt version 5.15.2 in /usr/lib

```

Just to give more data, I run into this issue on Ubuntu 20.10 with lxqt, which does not even really have HiDPI support.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11762725/103959250-2f09b980-511d-11eb-8be6-23495027b791.png)

If I run
`~$ echo $QT_SCALE_FACTOR`
It returns nothing, so I don't believe any hi DPI settings that lxqt could use are on.

My QT version is 5.14.2 

The interface renders just fine when launching OBS in the Cinnamon DE, on the same computer, as opposed to lxqt.
Edit: this is also a 1080p display with no hidpi settings on in general

Font scaling less than 1 doesnt appear to work in any Qt programs, it seems Qt does not support them (read: is a Qt bug) nor make it easy to try and avoid this bug. I recommend you force a compatible dpi/rounding value for all qt applications. Choose your favorite from some of the available flavors.
`QT_SCALE_FACTOR_ROUNDING_POLICY=Round`
`QT_FONT_DPI=96`
`QT_SCALE_FACTOR=1`

For others, is your scale factor greater than 1? I cannot replicate the issue on qt 5.15.2 with fractional scaling greater than 1 (1.1 -> 2.0 all render fine). Are you using other more exotic attempts at hidpi? Please provide exactly how you are configuring hidpi support.

I have set the scaling factor to 1 until this is resolved, but having users define env vars is not a permanent solution. People who don't have these set will still have the issue and might not know about (these) env vars.
of course, the permanent solution is to get Qt to fix their bug for users with scaling factors less than 1.

This is still an issue, and I'm on Cinnamon on Manjaro Linux. I use text scaling of 0.8 as opposed to text scaling of 1.0 on HIDPI monitor.

Here's few screenshots for comparison.

![flameshot_2021-01-17__02_49_57_PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73155407/104830938-a71d6f80-58d3-11eb-93f7-75cc94d9d43e.png)
![flameshot_2021-01-17__02_50_17_PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73155407/104830939-a8e73300-58d3-11eb-9cb3-674349c4d6bf.png)

Could you perhaps include the provided QT_SCALE_FACTOR and QT_FONT_DPI in the build so then they scale properly based on whatever the scaling is set on the system instead of hardcoding it.

Previous build didn't seem to have this issue, but in the new build it has this issue, so whatever you had before wasn't an issue.
The fix I committed doesn't use any hardcoding, it just removes fractional scaling seeing as it misbehaves on Linux. We'll revisit in future for sure.

I'm still experiencing this issue ([see my question on the OBS forums](https://obsproject.com/forum/threads/weird-ui-artifact-glitch-after-installing-obs-on-linux-mint.139216/)), is there a permanent fix for this?

I'm using OBS (v26.1.1) on Mint (v20.1 - Cinnamon) on a Dell 4k monitor running at double (Hi DPI) user interface scale. I can run `export QT_SCALE_FACTOR=1.2` and launch OBS from the command line for a quick/incomplete fix but I have no such luck launching the app from the desktop icon or task bar.

Hi,
Same issue here with that program, RPCS3 : https://github.com/RPCS3/rpcs3/issues/8095

Solution is to launch program with : `QT_ENABLE_HIGHDPI_SCALING=0`

Because, `QT_AUTO_SCREEN_SCALE_FACTOR` was replaced with `QT_ENABLE_HIGHDPI_SCALING` in Qt 5.14.

> I'm still experiencing this issue ([see my question on the OBS forums](https://obsproject.com/forum/threads/weird-ui-artifact-glitch-after-installing-obs-on-linux-mint.139216/)), is there a permanent fix for this?
> 
> I'm using OBS (v26.1.1) on Mint (v20.1 - Cinnamon) on a Dell 4k monitor running at double (Hi DPI) user interface scale. I can run `export QT_SCALE_FACTOR=1.2` and launch OBS from the command line for a quick/incomplete fix but I have no such luck launching the app from the desktop icon or task bar.

You could edit your obs.desktop to fit with the correct launching command.

I am also still experiencing this issue. If I use QT_SCALE_FACTOR=.5 obs it works, but everytahing is super tiny...

I figured out that it has something to do with multi-screen setups. If I unplug my second screen, everything works like a charm, even without the QT_SCALE_FACTOR=.5 workaround.
In sway, running obs with QT_SCALE_FACTOR=1 works fine, but any other scaling factor make obs controls unclicable.
